comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: SS=Steam Ship. Have just been looking at the original stereo pair of this scene catalogue.nli.ie/Record/STP_2746/Image?lookfor=http://www... The centres are too far apart for "parallel" stereos. You get a headache if you try to straighten your eyes. You get the stereo effect by using the "cross-eyed" method.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I found this in a genealogy website. Whether it is the same Adolphine or not is a moot point. Apparently is started out as the "Napier" from Baltimore USA. And SS stands for "Sailing Ship" yer man Crosaire hadn't a clue about maritime matters, if you'll pardon the pun;-) Looking at the shot I note that the "yards" are crossed, probably because the vessels are so closely packed together. that was usually a sign that the ship was not ready for sea and expected to be docked for some time. "Adolphine" was born in 1833 in Baltimore/Maryland under the name of "Napier". Main dimensions: length 123 feet - 6 inches, breadth 29" - 0", depth 14" - 6", and measured 469-53/95 American tons, had 2 decks - 3 full rigged masts, square stem - no gallions and billet head. You will find her in the Baltimore shipping register under the date of May 2 - 1848. Her owners had been Messrs. George Christian Denke of Baltimore. Her masters had been during the years she sailed under American flag - Master George Maple, Master R.H. Ramsey, Master Wm. M. Haynie. Between 1848 and 1849 "Napier" changed hands and flag. In 1849 the "Napier" starts a new career. jimsgenealogy.net/hartung/adolphine.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Yes, I found that too - What's a "square stem"?  This photo looks like a square stern.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I always understood it to be the bow or certainly the extension of the keel that rose up to the bow of the ship/boat.  I googled it and they confirm my belief.  Not sure what a square stem would look like.  The stern of the Adolphine looks like a square one to me!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It looks as though she was called the "Adolpine" from 1851 to at least 1869 and she plied the Bremerhaven to Baltimore USA route for much of that time.  This was not long after the famine in Ireland and the great emigration of population that followed it.  The Irish trade would probably have been a lucrative one at that time as desperate people rushed to get off the island to a better life.  We could be looking at an interesting insight into the history of emigration?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Went back to original, and think it says at the very top: FOUR HOURS [image of ship] ON BOARD PLEASURE TRIP to LAMBAY [THE STEAMER?] "WILLIAM HALL" If it is 4 hours, then that rules out the June 1861 date from the Irish Times advert which gives 6 hours duration. On the other hand, this photo must surely have been taken before 29 June 1863, as the Irish Times has the directors of the Kingstown and Dublin Steam Packet Company:
anxious to meet the requirements of the public, and to promote the interests of the shareholders, have determined to start a steamer every hour from either end. Being disappointed in the purchase of a new steamer, they have for the present chartered the pretty tug boat William Hall, to perform the service. This will prove a great boon to the public as the hours of starting had, up to the present, been so inconsistent as to induce several persons to avail themselves of the railway...
So the William Hall was occupied plying between Dublin and Kingstown after June 1863...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

Notice. I hereby caution the Public against giving my Wife, Catherine Mulligan, otherwise Cairns, and Credit in my name from this date. Anthony Mulligan, 3 Wood-lane, Dublin. June 26th, 1861.
Ooh-er!
